meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>towel</radical> and make it <radical>long</radical>. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your <kanji>notebook</kanji>, which you will write all your notes in.
reading_mnemonic: Inside your long towel <kanji>notebook</kanji> you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading>" (ちょう).

meaning_mnemonic: The type of <radical>insect</radical> that ruins your <radical>writing</radical> is the <kanji>mosquito</kanji>. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing.
reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>mosquito</kanji> noise sounds like it's driving a tiny <reading>ca</reading>r (か) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car?

meaning_mnemonic: There is an <radical>insect</radical> on the <radical>roof</radical> in a <radical>spoon</radical>. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a <kanji>snake</kanji> to your roof.
reading_mnemonic: Why don't you just bring a <kanji>snake</kanji> up to the roof yourself? Because snakes are <reading>heavy</reading> (へび).

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>shellfish</radical> are worth a <radical>fortune</radical> because you decided to <kanji>paste</kanji> your fortune to the shellfish.
reading_mnemonic: You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use <kanji>paste</kanji> to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)!" Paste.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>landslide</radical> <radical>measurement</radical> <kanji>humiliate</kanji>s you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet.
reading_mnemonic: Your friends and coworkers <kanji>humiliate</kanji> you more by making <reading>joke</reading>s (じょく). "Uh oh, I heard it might rain later, I hope you don't drown in the inch of water that's coming!"

meaning_mnemonic: Melt down this <radical>gold</radical> <radical>book</radical> and recast it as a <kanji>flower pot</kanji>. A solid gold book is too heavy to hold and too shiny to read, but a solid gold flower pot would make a fancy new addition to your garden.
reading_mnemonic: The gold <kanji>flower pot</kanji> has a <reading>hatch</reading> (はち) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the flower pot!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>gate</radical> makes the <radical>sound</radical> of <kanji>darkness</kanji>. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to taste the <kanji>darkness</kanji> and discover that it is so <reading>yummy</reading> (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy!

meaning_mnemonic: In this <radical>building</radical> there's a <radical>small</radical> <radical>sun</radical> that's <radical>small</radical>. They keep this small, small sun inside of a <kanji>crevice</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: They keep the sun in the <kanji>crevice</kanji> because this is a place where people <reading>ski</reading> (すき).

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> falls off a <radical>tree</radical> and lands in your <radical>eye</radical> where it turns to <kanji>frost</kanji>. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell off the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye.
reading_mnemonic: This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo <kanji>frost</kanji> idea because you are a <reading>shemo</reading> (しも). An emo who goes by she pronouns.

meaning_mnemonic: You’re so hungry that you <radical>eat</radical> a <radical>table</radical> so you won’t <kanji>starve</kanji>. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive.
reading_mnemonic: After you finish the table, you still feel like you might <kanji>starve</kanji> so you decide to eat every <reading>key</reading> (き) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve.

meaning_mnemonic: If you have nothing to <radical>eat</radical> but your <radical>ego</radical>, you'll <kanji>starve</kanji>. You can't eat it, and your ego is keeping you from accepting actual food or help from other people.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>starve</kanji> (thanks ego) and turn into a <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle (が). As your stomach aches, your skin turns gray and you slowly harden into a crouched position.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>mysterious</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> there is some <kanji>livestock</kanji>. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed.
reading_mnemonic: Your favorite member of the mysterious <kanji>livestock</kanji> crew is a little <reading>chick</reading> (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings.

meaning_mnemonic: You drive your <radical>scooter</radical> off this <radical>cliff</radical>, holding your <radical>cross</radical> tight to your chest, at a <kanji>swift</kanji> speed.
reading_mnemonic: Because you had such a <kanji>swift</kanji> take off, you didn't notice that your <reading>jean</reading>s (じん) were ripped right off your body. Until now.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>horse</radical> may look <radical>odd</radical> but it’s actually perfect for <kanji>horse riding</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Before <kanji>horse riding</kanji>, you’ll need the <reading>key</reading> (き) to access the stable and let out the odd horse you'll be riding.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> are <radical>mysterious</radical>ly appearing in the <radical>rice paddy</radical>. No matter what you do to them, they continue to <kanji>amass</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As the flowers <kanji>amass</kanji> it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby <reading>chick</reading>s (ちく) are amassing in the rice paddy as well.

meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>shrimp</radical> on <radical>ice</radical> at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been <kanji>exhaust</kanji>ed. It's all gone! You never thought they'd <kanji>use up</kanji> their shrimp supply so quickly.
reading_mnemonic: How could the store <kanji>use up</kanji> its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their <reading>jean</reading>s (じん) . Aha! The culprit!

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>cleat</radical> to climb a <radical>tree</radical> and your <radical>hair</radical> gets the same <kanji>coloring</kanji> as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red!
reading_mnemonic: This cool <kanji>coloring</kanji> can only happen because you turned yourself into a <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones.

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>soul</radical> has an <radical>idea</radical> it's just a <kanji>recollection</kanji> of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now.
reading_mnemonic: Your soul is sending you a <kanji>recollection</kanji> right now of... your past life as a farmer in <reading>Ok</reading>lahoma (おく). You see yourself farming and sweating and living a wonderful life. Hmm, maybe you should move to Oklahoma and live the simple life again.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>form</radical> and you begin to <kanji>melt</kanji>. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt.
reading_mnemonic: The only way to reverse the <kanji>melt</kanji> process is to eat some <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt!

meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>rake</radical> in for a <radical>measurement</radical> but it is <kanji>resistant</kanji>. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others.
reading_mnemonic: Because the rake is persistently <kanji>resistant</kanji>, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck <reading>tie</reading> (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>foot</radical>, as your <radical>mama</radical> says, was given the <radical>task</radical> to <kanji>dance</kanji>. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance!
reading_mnemonic: You both <kanji>dance</kanji> so much that you develop an <reading>odo</reading>r (おど). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>servant</radical> uses a <radical>stool</radical> to break open <radical>shellfish</radical>. This is really <kanji>clever</kanji>, because shucking shellfish is a lot of work. It's also a <kanji>wise</kanji> move, because it'll save him time that he can spend on all his other servant chores.
reading_mnemonic: "Yes, more <kanji>clever</kanji> than you!" he yells, tearing off his servant's disguise. "It is I, <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai. I won't let you eat these shellfish. I'm taking them back to the sea, where they belong!"

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>light</radical> shines on your <radical>forehead</radical> in your <radical>car</radical> with a great <kanji>radiance</kanji>. The car you are in is a convertible, so the light shines right onto your big bald forehead. The light has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from this light hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>radiance</kanji> is the <reading>key</reading> (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car.

meaning_mnemonic: There's <radical>power</radical>, <radical>power</radical>, and <radical>power</radical> stacked on top of the <radical>moon</radical>, <kanji>threaten</kanji>ing to bring it down!
reading_mnemonic: This extra power-filled moon is now trying to <kanji>threaten</kanji> the safety of <reading>きょう</reading>と. All of きょうと is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s isn't actually a canopy of trees at all. When you look closely, you see these trees are actually giant stalks of <kanji>hemp</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Who planted all this <kanji>hemp</kanji>? Your <reading>ma</reading>ma (ま) did.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Fire</radical> you use to light up the <radical>street</radical> needs to go in a <kanji>lamp</kanji>. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night.
reading_mnemonic: These street <kanji>lamp</kanji>s were first used in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. It was the most advanced city after all. And more people were out at night in とうきょう than anywhere else in Japan. So they needed lamps to light things up!

meaning_mnemonic: When a flower looks like a <radical>mouth</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> that reach up to <radical>heaven</radical>, you know it's in <kanji>blossom</kanji>. It's all opened up like a mouth, and the pistil and stamen are like horns reaching up to heaven for its sunlight and rain.
reading_mnemonic: If it's shaped like a mouth with horns poking out of it, you know it's going to be a tough little <kanji>blossom</kanji>. That's why you'll need a <reading>saw</reading> (さ) if you've got any hope of cutting it down for your blossom collection.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>dirt</radical> needs a  <radical>clown</radical> in it if you want to <kanji>cultivate</kanji> good crops. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing?
reading_mnemonic: Before you can start this whole <kanji>cultivation</kanji> process however, you have to say <reading>bye</reading> (ばい) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt.

meaning_mnemonic: If you try to put your <radical>soul</radical> into <radical>every</radical>thing, you'll <kanji>regret</kanji> it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>regret</kanji> is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but <reading>kay</reading>aking (かい). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> has a lot of <radical>power</radical> that is <radical>power</radical> it gets from the <radical>power</radical> of every <kanji>armpit</kanji> of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices.
reading_mnemonic: This is a pretty <reading>wacky</reading> (わき) <kanji>armpit</kanji> image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life?

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>scooter</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> with a <radical>pig</radical> riding on it will be able to <kanji>accomplish</kanji> anything.
reading_mnemonic: It was even able to successfully <kanji>accomplish</kanji> a feat that involved it jumping its scooter right into a <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい), swinging back and forth, then jumping off.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>king</radical> gives you a <radical>knife</radical> you become part of his <kanji>squad</kanji>. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>squad</kanji> is led by <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo, so it's basically a 50/50 shot that the king is gonna die.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>surplus</radical> will cover all the <radical>dirt</radical> with <kanji>paint</kanji>. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors.
reading_mnemonic: You touch the <kanji>paint</kanji> in the dirt with your <reading>toe</reading> (と) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>surplus</radical> of <radical>ladle</radical>s laid out <kanji>diagonally</kanji> in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there.
reading_mnemonic: In front of this <kanji>diagonal</kanji> pattern is a <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>district</radical> is full of <radical>weapons</radical>, but everyone prefers to <kanji>punch</kanji> each other. When everyone's armed, things can escalate quickly, so it's better to stick to fists to be safe.
reading_mnemonic: The district residents <kanji>punch</kanji> each other in front of the <reading>王</reading> (おう). These punching matches are actually gladiatorial battles for the 王's entertainment.

meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>cliff</radical>, the <radical>pope</radical> is holding a <kanji>shield</kanji>. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off.
reading_mnemonic: The light of the pope's <kanji>shield</kanji> begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's <reading>June</reading> (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell!

meaning_mnemonic: You need to feed this <radical>grain</radical> to a <radical>flower</radical> wearing <radical>turkey</radical> on a <radical>stool</radical> so you start the <kanji>harvest</kanji>. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them.
reading_mnemonic: You're just starting to <kanji>harvest</kanji> the grains when an angry <reading>cock</reading> (かく) shows up! He's mad because these are his grains and you're about to harvest them and feed them to a turkey instead of him.
